trans-unit.source: Scalability of Service Fabric Services
trans-unit.target: Scalability of Service Fabric Services

trans-unit.source: Describes how to scale Service Fabric services
trans-unit.target: Describes how to scale Service Fabric services

trans-unit.source: Scaling Service Fabric Applications
trans-unit.target: Scaling Service Fabric Applications

trans-unit.source: Service Fabric makes it easy to build scalable applications by load balancing services, partitions and replicas on all the nodes in a cluster.
trans-unit.target: Service Fabric makes it easy to build scalable applications by load balancing services, partitions and replicas on all the nodes in a cluster.

trans-unit.source: This enables maximum resource utilization.
trans-unit.target: This enables maximum resource utilization.

trans-unit.source: High Scale for Service Fabric Applications can be achieved in two ways:
trans-unit.target: High Scale for Service Fabric Applications can be achieved in two ways:

trans-unit.source: Scaling at the partition level
trans-unit.target: Scaling at the partition level

trans-unit.source: Scaling at the service name level
trans-unit.target: Scaling at the service name level

trans-unit.source: Scaling at the partition level
trans-unit.target: Scaling at the partition level

trans-unit.source: Service Fabric supports partitioning an individual service into multiple smaller partitions.
trans-unit.target: Service Fabric supports partitioning an individual service into multiple smaller partitions.

trans-unit.source: The <link><linkText>Partitioning overview</linkText><title></title></link> provides information on the types of partitioning schemes that are supported.
trans-unit.target: The <link><linkText>Partitioning overview</linkText><title></title></link> provides information on the types of partitioning schemes that are supported.

trans-unit.source: The replicas of each partition are spread across the nodes in the cluster.
trans-unit.target: The replicas of each partition are spread across the nodes in the cluster.

trans-unit.source: Consider a service using the ranged partitioning scheme with a low key of 0, high key of 99 and 4 partitions.
trans-unit.target: Consider a service using the ranged partitioning scheme with a low key of 0, high key of 99 and 4 partitions.

trans-unit.source: In a 3 node cluster, the service might be laid out with four replicas sharing the resources on each node as shown below.
trans-unit.target: In a 3 node cluster, the service might be laid out with four replicas sharing the resources on each node as shown below.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Partition Layout With Three Nodes</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Partition Layout With Three Nodes</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Increasing the number of nodes will allow Service Fabric to utilize the resources on the new nodes by moving some of the replicas to empty nodes.
trans-unit.target: Increasing the number of nodes will allow Service Fabric to utilize the resources on the new nodes by moving some of the replicas to empty nodes.

trans-unit.source: Thus, increasing the number of nodes to four will now have three replicas running on each node (of different partitions) allowing for better resource utilization and performance.
trans-unit.target: Thus, increasing the number of nodes to four will now have three replicas running on each node (of different partitions) allowing for better resource utilization and performance.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Partition Layout With Four Nodes</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Partition Layout With Four Nodes</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Scaling at the service name level
trans-unit.target: Scaling at the service name level

trans-unit.source: A service instance is a specific named instance of an application name and a service type name (see <link><linkText>Service Fabric Application Lifecycle</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: A service instance is a specific named instance of an application name and a service type name (see <link><linkText>Service Fabric Application Lifecycle</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: It is during service creation that you specify the partition scheme (<link><linkText>Partitioning Service Fabric Services</linkText><title></title></link> to be used.
trans-unit.target: It is during service creation that you specify the partition scheme (<link><linkText>Partitioning Service Fabric Services</linkText><title></title></link> to be used.

trans-unit.source: The first level of scaling is by service names.
trans-unit.target: The first level of scaling is by service names.

trans-unit.source: You can create new instances of a service, with a different level of partitioning, as your older service instances become busy.
trans-unit.target: You can create new instances of a service, with a different level of partitioning, as your older service instances become busy.

trans-unit.source: This allows new service consumers to use less busy service instances in favor of busier ones.
trans-unit.target: This allows new service consumers to use less busy service instances in favor of busier ones.

trans-unit.source: An option to increase capacity, or to increase or decrease partition counts, is to create a new service instance with a new partition scheme.
trans-unit.target: An option to increase capacity, or to increase or decrease partition counts, is to create a new service instance with a new partition scheme.

trans-unit.source: The complexity is that any consuming clients need to know when and how to use a differently named service.
trans-unit.target: The complexity is that any consuming clients need to know when and how to use a differently named service.

trans-unit.source: Example Scenario – Embedded Dates
trans-unit.target: Example Scenario – Embedded Dates

trans-unit.source: One possible scenario would be to use date information as part of the service name.
trans-unit.target: One possible scenario would be to use date information as part of the service name.

trans-unit.source: For example, you could use service instance with a specific name for all customers that joined in 2013 and a another name for customers that joined in 2014.
trans-unit.target: For example, you could use service instance with a specific name for all customers that joined in 2013 and a another name for customers that joined in 2014.

trans-unit.source: This naming scheme allows for programmatic increase in names depending on the date (as 2014 approaches, the service instance for 2014 can be created on demand).
trans-unit.target: This naming scheme allows for programmatic increase in names depending on the date (as 2014 approaches, the service instance for 2014 can be created on demand).

trans-unit.source: However, this approach is based on the clients using application specific naming information that is outside of the scope of Service Fabric knowledge.
trans-unit.target: However, this approach is based on the clients using application specific naming information that is outside of the scope of Service Fabric knowledge.

trans-unit.source: Using a Naming Convention: In 2013 when your application goes live you create one service called fabric:/app/service2013.
trans-unit.target: Using a Naming Convention: In 2013 when your application goes live you create one service called fabric:/app/service2013.

trans-unit.source: Towards the second quarter of 2013 you create another service called fabric:/app/service2014.
trans-unit.target: Towards the second quarter of 2013 you create another service called fabric:/app/service2014.

trans-unit.source: Both these services are of the same service type.
trans-unit.target: Both these services are of the same service type.

trans-unit.source: In this approach, your client will have to have logic on constructing the appropriate service name based on the year.
trans-unit.target: In this approach, your client will have to have logic on constructing the appropriate service name based on the year.

trans-unit.source: Using a Lookup Service: Another pattern is to provide a secondary “lookup service” which can provide the name of the service for a desired key.
trans-unit.target: Using a Lookup Service: Another pattern is to provide a secondary “lookup service” which can provide the name of the service for a desired key.

trans-unit.source: New service instances can then be created by the lookup service.
trans-unit.target: New service instances can then be created by the lookup service.

trans-unit.source: The lookup service itself does not retain any application data, but only data about the service names that it creates.
trans-unit.target: The lookup service itself does not retain any application data, but only data about the service names that it creates.

trans-unit.source: Thus in same year based example above the client would first contact the lookup service to find out the name of the service handling data for a given year and then use that service name for performing the actual operation.
trans-unit.target: Thus in same year based example above the client would first contact the lookup service to find out the name of the service handling data for a given year and then use that service name for performing the actual operation.

trans-unit.source: The result of the first lookup can be cached.
trans-unit.target: The result of the first lookup can be cached.
